courses.description:
Scrum is becoming the most popular of the Agile Frameworks for delivering software applications and complex products.
By the end of this course you will know what the Scrum Framework is all about and be able to contribute to the success of your projects using the Scrum methods and processes.
Learn and Master the Scrum Roles, Events and Artifacts, Enhancing Your Career Prospects and Enabling You to Become a Valued Member of Your Agile Scrum Project Team
Be able to explain what the Scrum Framework is and how it will make your organisation more efficient in developing new products
Understand the three pillars of the Agile Scrum Framework: Transparency, Inspection, Adaptation. And the concept of Empirical Process Control where decisions are made based only on what is known
Feel confident participating in the formal and informal Scrum Events


Learn Why Using Agile Scrum is So Powerful in the Rapid Development of New Products
Scrum is most often used to manage complex software and product development using iterative and incremental processes
Delivering complex products using Scrum is all about creating quality, working versions that provide the highest business value in the shortest possible time
Scrum significantly increases productivity and reduces time to market compared to the traditional waterfall project management processes
The course is structured around the three Scrum perspectives of Roles, Events and Artifacts
Section one includes and overview of the Scrum Framework and the Scrum Process Flow
Section Two introduces the the Scrum Roles of Product Owner, Scrum Master and the Development Team
Section Three focuses on the Scrum events, or meetings that need to take place
Section Four  includes the Scrum Artifacts that are needed for monitoring and reporting the status of the works
Section Five is where we get into the practical aspects of working with the Scrum Framework including again the Roles, Events and Artifacts
Section Six is where we wind down a little and discus the theory behind developing products using the Scrum Framework and Processes
At the end of each section there is a short multi-choice quiz to keep you on your toes
There are also downloadable spreadsheets and checklists in the resources area of lectures
target_audience: Anyone who is involved in software and product development using Agile/Scrum framework: Product Owners, Sponsors, Stakeholders, Project Managers, Business Analysts, Developers, Designers, Architects…

requirements: Willingness or Interest to learn about SAFe SPC Certification Prep for Success.
courses.description:
|| UNOFFICIAL COURSE ||
IMPORTANT Before Enrolling:
This course is not intended to replace studying any official vendor material for certification exams, is not endorsed by the certification vendor, and you will not be getting the official certification study material or a voucher as a part of this course.
This course provides a deep dive into the Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) and the critical role of a SAFe Program Consultant (SPC) in leading agile transformations. Designed for professionals looking to gain expertise in SAFe practices, this course covers the foundational principles, framework configurations, and implementation strategies necessary for scaling Agile across large enterprises.
The course begins with an introduction to SAFe, outlining its origins, evolution, and why it has become the leading framework for scaling Agile methodologies. Participants will gain insight into the SPC role, exploring the responsibilities, strategic influence, and value SPCs bring to organizations undergoing agile transformations.
A strong emphasis is placed on Lean-Agile thinking, where learners will explore the Lean-Agile mindset, core Lean principles, and the Agile Manifesto’s relevance to SAFe. These foundational concepts set the stage for understanding how Agile methodologies align with enterprise-wide business objectives.
Participants will take a deep dive into the SAFe framework, covering its various configurations—Essential SAFe, Large Solution SAFe, Portfolio SAFe, and Full SAFe. This section highlights the core values and principles of SAFe, the House of Lean, and the essential components that enable large-scale agility. A detailed look at Agile teams and Agile Release Trains (ARTs) will provide learners with an understanding of how value is delivered through synchronization and alignment across teams.
The course also explores the SPC’s role in leading and sustaining transformations. Learners will be introduced to the SPC certification process, the benefits of becoming an SPC, and the key responsibilities required to guide organizations through agile adoption. This section delves into strategies for coaching and mentoring leaders and teams, fostering a Lean-Agile culture, and overcoming resistance to change.
A critical component of the course is the SAFe implementation roadmap, which walks learners through the steps required to prepare for and execute a SAFe transformation. Topics include assessing organizational readiness, defining a transformation strategy, designing an implementation roadmap, and effectively communicating change to stakeholders. The course highlights leadership qualities necessary for guiding large-scale change initiatives and maintaining strategic alignment.
As Agile adoption scales across enterprises, understanding team dynamics, Agile Release Trains, and the roles of Scrum Masters and Product Owners becomes essential. This course provides insights into these roles within the SAFe framework, ensuring learners understand how leadership and collaboration foster high-performing teams.
Lean Portfolio Management (LPM) is another key focus area, where learners will explore how SAFe aligns business strategy with execution. The course covers investment funding, governance, and portfolio-level agility, along with key performance indicators and metrics to measure the success of Agile transformations. Innovation and value stream management are also discussed, providing insights into sustaining agility in a rapidly evolving business environment.
The final section of the course delves into critical SAFe practices such as Agile architecture, DevOps, governance, and risk management. Participants will learn about system thinking, continuous delivery pipelines, and strategies for managing dependencies and synchronization across Agile Release Trains. By understanding these advanced concepts, learners will be well-equipped to drive SAFe transformations in complex organizational structures.
By the end of this course, participants will have a comprehensive understanding of SAFe, the SPC role, and the skills necessary to lead Agile transformations at scale.
Whether preparing for SPC certification or looking to enhance Agile expertise, this course provides the theoretical foundation and strategic insights needed to drive enterprise agility and business success.
Thank you
target_audience: Aspiring & Current SAFe Program Consultants (SPCs) – Professionals looking to become SPC-certified and lead Agile transformations within organizations.
Agile Coaches & Transformation Leaders – Those responsible for guiding teams and enterprises through Agile adoption and scaling.
Scrum Masters & Agile Practitioners – Individuals who want to deepen their knowledge of SAFe and expand their ability to support Agile teams.
Product Owners & Product Managers – Professionals seeking to align product strategy with Agile execution in a scaled environment.
Project & Program Managers – Leaders managing large initiatives who need to apply SAFe principles for effective execution and delivery.
Enterprise & Solution Architects – Those involved in designing Agile-friendly architectures that support SAFe implementations.
Lean Portfolio Managers & Business Leaders – Executives and decision-makers aiming to optimize strategic alignment, funding, and governance using SAFe.
IT & Engineering Leaders – CIOs, CTOs, and department heads who want to understand how SAFe drives enterprise agility and innovation.
If you are looking to lead Agile transformations, coach high-performing teams, and scale Agile across an enterprise, this course is perfect for you!

courses.title: Succeed in P3O Foundation exam on first attempt (EN)
courses.bio: More than 200 exam questions with answers to pass the P3O® certification
courses.description:
P3O® Foundation (Portfolio, Program and Project Offices) is a business model for making decisions and supporting business changes within an organization. It consists of several single or multiple physical or virtual structures, i.e. offices (permanent and / or temporary), offering a mix of central and localized functions and services, integration with governance arrangements and larger activities such as other business support functions.
The Foundation level introduces the P3O® Method and aims to confirm that you know and understand the P3O® Method well enough to be able to work effectively with or as a member of a management office, team working in an environment supporting the P3O® principles.


This training contains:
1. 175 standard MCQ exercises in English, corrected and modeled on the passing exams for the P3O® Foundation certification.
2. P3O® Foundation exam course material.pdf
3. Glossary P3O® Foundation.pdf
4. P3O® Foundation exam course material.pdf
The questions are regularly updated so that they are always up to date with the versions and formalisms of the official exam.
Futhermore, this training consist in 2 quick tests and 2 practical exams to be taken under the same conditions as the official exam (75 questions in 1 hour, of which a minimum of 38/75 or 50% to obtain certification) :
Quick test 01: 25 MCQs
Quick test 02: 25 MCQs
Exam 01: 75 MCQ
Exam 02: 75 MCQ
Finally, the tests offered are very complete with an affordable price compared to other P3O® Foundation courses, present on UDEMY.
#p3o, #p3o foundation, #project office, #p3o fondation, #project program portfolio offices, #project management

requirements: Some familiarity with project based working is useful to follow the concepts of risk management as applied to Agile and Waterfall
If you've a strong grasp to start the Fast-Track will be all you need - Its the What to Do
Where Fast-Track presumes more knowledge than you have then dip-into the Master-Class to build, reinforce or refresh How-To details
courses.description:
One topic, Two courses - A two speed risk management course.
The fast-track is under 30 minutes of step-by-step WHAT to do
The videos and Workbook-manual guide you through what's needed at work to Manage, Lead or Oversee and Facilitate risk in your projects, programs and portfolios.
The Master-class is 13hours of detailed HOW-to using the same Workbook and slides as the Fast-Track
Dip into the Masterclass videos only where you feel you need or want more guidance than the fast-track gives.
*IF* you also want to take PMI or AXELOS/PeopleCert exams then use the two 'exam conversion' modules to understand what exam specific vocabularies and process models are overlaid on real-world risk management.
~~"~~
These two courses are for Project (and Program or Portfolio) managers and PMO Analysts, Scrum Masters, Team Subject Matter experts and Project Sponsors and Product Owners who need competency in how to handle risk.
Learn a step by step framework of WHAT to do grounded in "Projects are delivered by people (so most of the arithmetic theory isn't too useful)". Plus here are the techniques, tips, tools and hints per step to give solid How-to that includes the adjustments required to work across the typical mixture of teams using Agile and Predictive product development ways of working.
The master class covers it all.
The Fast-Track is just the structured what to do - suitable if you've already got some idea of how to lead workshops and define risk scales (etc).
Your ideal situation would be that your starting a project and feel some guidance on "how to really do risk" from day one with the sponsor through every day with the team to last day and risk handover. Ideal because the WorkBook's guidance is written as exercises to be applied to your current project to create real governance documents. If you've not got a current project then I've provided a scenario based on a fictionalised combination of some of my past projects.
I've practiced projects as PM and PMO lead for 30 years and taught other people's risk courses on and off over the last 20. Those course from the big global training companies have always needed a big dose of reality which is what I've built into this course.
The result is a course unlike any other I know of because it doesn't treat the world as 'text-book'. In fact I've recorded it because I think big training company courses and project risk textbooks and chapters (in the PRINCE2 guide and the PMBoK-Guide) are fit more for exams than reality. Since the course is IMHO reality I've included two 'exam conversion modules' for those who DO want to take the exams.
I'm expert enough to be unsure what a risk is (!) but I know its not 'A Single and instantaneous event-based-cause that leads to A Single quantifiable consequence for A Single stakeholder'. That is too naive. Too simple for the world I work in and for the one you're in too. I know that identification is key to all that follows. I'll share with you how to define responses (they are what actually matter!) so defining "A" risk isn't so important when we know our set of valid responses (plural).
I'll start you off with what does running each workshop of each step look and feel like. In the Master-Class I'll give your a slew of tools to use and I'll suggest how to apply to your own project, how to build responses into the baseline - because we only have one set of people to deliver the project and handle the risk. I'll cover how reporting of project status integrates risk management.
[ Of course after investing your effort you'll probably appreciate a way to demonstrate the results so I've also been mindful to giving you real world skills that substantially support efforts to gain CAPM®/ PMP®/ IMPA-abcd/ PRINCE2agile® and PRINCE2® exam/ RMP/ MoR etc. The course includes the supplements for translating to exam needs.
target_audience: PMO Analysts, Project managers, Project Sponsors

The course is useful to people studying PMP, CAPM, PRINCE2, RMP etc. The structure and principles match BUT the master class goes deeper than the exam need and is REAL-WORLD not exam. The text books are simplistic, reality is complex.

courses.bio: Agile, Scrum framework
objectives: Agile and Scrum framework
requirements: NO
courses.description:
Agile and Scrum framework is hot topic in software project management, this course provide the need information to start your journey using Agile and Scrum in your work and gain the need knowledge for be agile, through out the course you will learn what is agile and what is scrum, scrum history, scrum roles, scrum ceremonies and scrum artifacts.
Agile is used now in every aspect of project management starting from software and forward to many other fields, and become a mindset by it's values and principle that provide guidance on how to deal with change and uncertainty.
Agile practices involve discovering requirements and developing solutions through the collaborative effort of self-organizing and cross-functional teams and their customer(s)/end user(s). It advocates adaptive planning, evolutionary development, early delivery, and continual improvement, and it encourages flexible responses to change.
It was popularized by the Manifesto for Agile Software Development. The values and principles espoused in this manifesto were derived from and underpin a broad range of software development frameworks, including Scrum.
While there is much anecdotal evidence that adopting agile practices and values improves the agility of software professionals, teams and organizations, the empirical evidence is mixed and hard to find.
Agile software development methods support a broad range of the software development life cycle. Some methods focus on the practices,  while some focus on managing the flow of work.
target_audience: Every one interest in knowing agile and scrum framework

courses.description:
Course Introduction:
This course offers an in-depth exploration of CMMI (Capability Maturity Model Integration), a proven framework for improving organizational processes. CMMI is essential for organizations looking to enhance their capabilities in project management, software engineering, and overall process improvement. The course covers the history of CMMI, its various levels, key process areas, and how to apply them for successful project planning, monitoring, and control. Designed for project managers, engineers, and organizational leaders, this course equips you with the tools and knowledge necessary to implement CMMI practices in real-world settings and improve project success rates.
Section 1: Overview of CMMI
This section provides a foundational understanding of CMMI. Students will learn about the history of CMMI and the framework itself, which integrates best practices for software and systems engineering, services, and product development. You will explore the various levels of maturity and capability in CMMI and understand how organizations can evaluate their processes and determine their maturity. This section sets the stage for understanding how the CMMI framework impacts project success.
Section 2: Project Management
The project management section delves into how CMMI applies to managing projects. Topics include equivalent staging, process management, and the various engineering and support process areas that impact project success. Students will understand the institutionalization process and how to implement standardized processes for ongoing improvement within projects. The lessons will focus on the management and execution of project strategies with clear goals and structured processes.
Section 3: Project Planning & Goals
This section covers the heart of project planning within the CMMI framework. Students will learn about the generic goals and practices that guide successful project planning. You'll explore Project Planning Goal 1, 2, and 3, and understand how these relate to different process areas. This will empower you to create robust plans that align with CMMI's guidelines and ensure your projects are effectively planned and executed.
Section 4: Project Monitoring & Control
Monitoring and controlling projects is a critical skill for successful execution. In this section, students will learn to monitor project progress, manage requirements, and handle supplier agreements effectively. The lessons will focus on critical process areas like configuration management and how these processes ensure that projects remain on track and within scope, ultimately leading to project success.
Section 5: Measurement & Analysis
This section introduces the concept of Measurement and Analysis (M&A) in CMMI, emphasizing the importance of collecting data to monitor process performance. Students will learn how to establish an effective measurement system, perform data analysis, and conduct reviews such as PPQA (Process and Product Quality Assurance) to ensure quality is maintained throughout the project lifecycle.
Section 6: Product Integration
In this section, students will gain insights into the processes that support the integration of various components of the product. You will explore requirements development, technical solutions, product integration, verification, and validation. Furthermore, risk management strategies are covered, preparing students to address potential issues proactively and maintain product quality at each stage.
Section 7: Organizational Process
Here, students will explore organizational process management within the CMMI framework. Topics include integrated project management, decision analysis, and resolution, as well as how to define and focus organizational processes. By focusing on process improvement through training and defining clear process goals, students will be equipped to drive organizational change and process improvement across their teams.
Section 8: Quantitative Project Management
The final section covers the advanced concepts of Quantitative Project Management and its relation to CMMI. Students will learn about organizational performance management, process performance, and the role of causal analysis and resolution. This section provides the tools needed for using data-driven techniques to refine project management strategies and ensure organizational processes evolve based on empirical evidence.
Conclusion:
By the end of this course, students will be equipped with a comprehensive understanding of the CMMI framework and how to apply it to optimize their organization's processes. They will gain the knowledge to implement and manage CMMI practices in project management, product integration, and organizational change. Whether you are a project manager, process owner, or organizational leader, this course will enable you to effectively use CMMI to enhance process maturity, reduce risks, and achieve greater project success.
target_audience: Project Managers: Those managing or overseeing projects and looking to implement CMMI (Capability Maturity Model Integration) to improve project management processes, team collaboration, and overall project success rates.

Process Improvement Professionals: Individuals working in roles focused on improving processes within their organization, such as process managers, quality assurance professionals, and business analysts.

Software Engineers and Development Teams: Software development teams who want to enhance their engineering practices and align their processes with CMMI standards for better product development and delivery.
Quality Assurance (QA) Engineers: QA professionals who are looking to understand how to integrate CMMI into quality management and process improvement.

Organizational Leaders and Executives: Senior management, decision-makers, and consultants who aim to implement CMMI across their organizations for increased efficiency and alignment with industry best practices.

courses.description:
IMPORTANT before enrolling:
This course is not intended to replace studying any official vendor material for certification exams, is not endorsed by the certification vendor, and you will not be getting the official certification study material or a voucher as a part of this course.
This comprehensive course is designed to provide you with an in-depth understanding of Prince2, a leading project management methodology.
Through a structured approach, you will gain extensive knowledge of Prince2's principles, themes, processes, and roles, ensuring you are well-prepared to manage projects effectively and efficiently.
PRINCE2 (Projects IN Controlled Environments) is a structured project management methodology widely used and recognized internationally. Developed by the UK government in the late 1980s, it has become a standard for managing projects effectively across various industries. PRINCE2 provides a systematic approach to planning, managing, and controlling projects through its comprehensive set of processes, principles, and themes.
We begin with an introduction to Prince2, exploring its origins and evolution. You'll understand why Prince2 has become a preferred methodology for many organizations and the advantages it offers in various project environments.
Next, we delve into the seven Prince2 principles that form the foundation of this methodology. You will learn about the importance of continuous business justification, learning from past experiences, clearly defined roles and responsibilities, progressive management, managing by exception, product focus, and the need to tailor these principles to specific project needs.
Our exploration continues with the Prince2 themes, which are crucial aspects of project management that must be continuously addressed. You will gain insights into the business case, organization, quality, plans, risk, change, and progress themes, learning how to tailor them to suit different project contexts.
The course then covers the Prince2 processes, providing a step-by-step guide to managing projects from initiation to closure. You will understand each process's objectives, activities, and deliverables, including initiating a project, directing a project, controlling a stage, managing product delivery, managing a stage boundary, and closing a project. Special focus will be given to customizing these processes to meet specific project requirements.
Roles and responsibilities within Prince2 are also thoroughly examined. You will learn about the various roles, including the executive, project manager, team manager, and project support, and understand how these roles collaborate to ensure project success. Customization of these roles for different project environments will also be discussed.
Finally, the course addresses the tailoring and adoption of Prince2 for various project environments, including integration with Agile methodologies. You will explore optimal practices and common pitfalls, ensuring you can adapt Prince2 to a wide range of projects effectively.
The course concludes with a detailed overview of Prince2 exam preparation, providing you with the knowledge and strategies needed to achieve certification.
PRINCE2 is a versatile and effective project management methodology that helps organizations deliver projects successfully by providing a structured framework for planning, managing, and controlling project activities.
By the end of this course, you will be equipped with the skills and confidence to apply Prince2 principles, themes, and processes in real-world projects, driving successful outcomes and achieving your project management goals.
Thank you

courses.bio: PMP 7th edition Exam Prep Questions and answers are explained well for students to deeply understand PMI Style.
courses.description:
What is the PMP?
Research indicates that employers will need to fill nearly 2.2 million new project-oriented roles each year through 2027. This means skilled project managers are in high demand. The PMP certification is designed by project professionals, for project professionals and validates that you are among the best—highly skilled in:
People: emphasizing the soft skills you need to effectively lead a project team in today's changing environment.
Process: reinforcing the technical aspects of successfully managing projects.
Business Environment: highlighting the connection between projects and organizational strategy.
PMP certification validates that you have the project leadership skills employers seek. The new PMP includes three key approaches:
Predictive (waterfall)
Agile
Hybrid
PMI is changing their style of questions rapidly, these question have been designed to set the student mind on the right way of answering the questions in the PMP exam. The most important PMP exam prep activity is to answer as many  questions as you possibly can to PASS with confident.
My advice to you is read pmbok6 twice before attempting the exam to make use of the question. understand the relationship between knowledge areas then do the exam. Do not memorize the answers and try to make use of them in building up your knowledge.
exam have been divided into 4 parts each part contain 50 Q. try to Get 85 out 100 in each part to ensure that you digest all type of questions.


What Skills Does the PMP Cover?
The PMP certification requires an understanding of the most important project leadership skills and practices across three domains as listed in the Examination Content Outline. You’ll be expected to apply this knowledge in the context of leading and managing predictive, agile and hybrid projects.
People Doman: The people domain represents 42% the questions on the PMP exam. It covers leading projects teams and managing stakeholders with effective interpersonal skills including:
team building
removing roadblocks
conflict management
Process Domain: The process domain represents 50% of the PMP exam. You’ll be tested on the technical skills to integrate all facets of project planning and management to realize project benefits such as:
budgeting  scheduling
managing risk
project methods and practices
Business Improvement Domain: This domain represents 8% of exam questions. You will need to understand the connection between the people and process within the business context. Domain topics include:
compliance
delivering value
organizational and business change
target_audience: Individuals who wants to achieve PMP Exam.

The Managing Project Work (PMI PMP) is course 2 of 28 of the Project Management Professional Certification Program (PMI-PMP). The course is aligned with the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK6) developed by the Project Management Institute (PMI).
Most projects aren't lucky enough to enjoy smooth sailing from beginning to end. Unforeseen events and difficulties usually crop up somewhere along the line. And these can steer a project off course. But don't worry, in this course, you'll learn how to direct and manage the work of a project. In addition, this course will show you how to monitor and control project work, to ensure work performance is in line with requirements. And how to leverage knowledge throughout the life cycle of the project.
1. The Direct and Manage Project Work Process
2. Inputs to Direct and Manage Project Work
3. Techniques for Directing and Managing Project Work
4. Direct and Manage Project Work Outputs
5. The Manage Project Knowledge Process
6. Monitoring and Controlling Project Work
7. Monitor and Control Project Work Process Inputs
8. Monitor and Control Project Work Process Techniques
9. Monitor and Control Project Work Outputs
10. Project Baselines Updates
11. Exercise: Managing Project Work and Knowledge
Throughout the course, you'll gain the tools and techniques necessary to deal with these inevitable challenges. From risk management strategies to techniques for handling scope changes and stakeholder issues, you'll develop the skills to keep your projects on track. This will ensure you can deliver value on time and within budget, even in the face of unexpected obstacles.
That’s it! Now go ahead and push that “Take this course” button, and see you on the inside!

What is Product Management and Product Ownership?


Product Management: A strategic field focused on guiding a product throughout its entire lifecycle. This includes:
Defining the product's vision and goals
Understanding the market, competitors, and customers
Creating a product roadmap
Collaborating with cross-functional teams (engineering, design, marketing, sales, etc.) to bring the product to market.


Product Ownership: A more tactical role often found within Agile development methodologies. Product Owners focus on:
Prioritizing the development backlog (list of features and tasks)
Working closely with the development team to ensure they understand product goals and requirements
Representing the voice of the customer and stakeholders


Role of a Product Owner
A Product Owner acts as the bridge between the product strategy defined by the product manager and the hands-on development team. Key responsibilities include:
Backlog Management: Maintaining and prioritizing the backlog to ensure the most important features get built first.
Customer Advocacy: Deeply understanding the customers' needs and pain points, and ensuring those are reflected in the product.
Agile Team Liaison: Working closely with developers, designers, and engineers, providing clear requirements and feedback throughout development.
Stakeholder Communication: Keeping stakeholders like executives and the sales team informed of progress, challenges, and upcoming features.


Why is Product Management Important for Companies?
Effective product management is essential to a company's success because it:
Enhances Customer Focus: Product managers/owners ensure products address real customer needs, leading to increased satisfaction and loyalty.
Drives Market Success: Strategic product management aligns products with market trends and competition, improving their chances of success.
Increases Efficiency: Clear vision and prioritization reduce wasted resources and enable teams to focus on the most essential work.
Promotes Innovation: Product managers foster a culture of experimentation, identifying new opportunities to address evolving customer needs.


How Developing Skills in Product Management Supports Career Development
Investing in product management skills can significantly boost your career:
High Demand: Product managers and owners are in demand across industries due to the growing emphasis on building customer-centric products.
Competitive Salaries: Product management roles often offer lucrative compensation.
Varied Opportunities: The skills translate to many roles, including business analyst, project manager, UX designer, or even launching your own startup.
Leadership Potential: Strong product managers naturally rise into leadership positions, driving strategic direction within organizations.

After completing each mock exam, carefully review the detailed explanations. This process will help bridge knowledge gaps, enhance your understanding of project management concepts, and prepare you for success in the PMP exam.

courses.title: Project Risk Management : PMP Certification
courses.bio: Strategically Managing Project Risks in Accordance with PMBOK 7: A Comprehensive Guide for Achieving Project Success"
objectives: This course will equip students with the expertise to develop a comprehensive Risk Management Plan, a fundamental element in project management.
Through this course, students will develop the expertise to manage a Risk Register and utilize diverse techniques to detect potential risks in projects.
Participants will acquire the skills to rank risks by their impact and probability, employing the risk probability and impact matrix to guide their decisions.
This course equips participants with the skills to numerically evaluate risks and utilize advanced techniques such as Monte Carlo simulations.
Students will have cultivated the skill of crafting strategic risk response plans, a critical competency for effectively mitigating identified risks.
You will be proficient in executing planned risk responses, enabling them to address real-time risks as they manifest during the project's lifecycle.
You will learn to manage project risks, by evaluating them, assessing response efficacy, and updating the Risk Register to maintain risk strategy effectiveness.

Project Risk Management : PMP Certificat: Key Concepts for Project Risk Management
Trends & Emerging Practices in Project Risk Management
Tailoring Considerations for Project Risk Management

requirements: Proficiency in basic mathematical and analytical skills is essential, particularly for risk analysis methods.
The ability to think critically and analyze situations is crucial for assessing and addressing project risks. So you can understand the various examples that are discussed through out this course.
Strong problem-solving skills are an asset, as risk management often involves addressing complex issues.
While not mandatory, prior experience in project work or a project management role can greatly enhance understanding and application of risk management principles.
courses.description:
In today's rapidly evolving and interconnected world, the ability to effectively manage risk is more critical than ever. Whether you find yourself in the realm of business, technology, healthcare, or any other field, the need to navigate the uncertainties and challenges that come with project management is ubiquitous. This course is your key to understanding and applying the fundamental principles of risk management, as outlined in the PMBOK Guide.
Risk management is not confined to any single sector. It's a dynamic skill set that transcends boundaries and disciplines, making it indispensable for professionals across industries. In this course, you'll discover the paramount importance of proactively identifying, analyzing and responding to potential risks in your projects.
The new world we live in is characterized by unprecedented levels of complexity, global interconnectivity, and rapid technological advancements. These factors introduce both opportunities and vulnerabilities, making the need for robust project risk management more pressing than ever. As such, this course equips you with the knowledge and tools necessary to thrive in this modern landscape.
In a world where innovation is the currency of progress, understanding how to manage risks is your competitive advantage. Whether you're a seasoned project manager or just starting your journey, this course empowers you to confidently navigate the complexities of modern projects, enhancing your ability to lead teams, meet objectives, and deliver successful outcomes.


This course provides comprehensive, in-depth coverage of the following topics:


Plan Risk Management: In this lecture, students will learn how to create a Risk Management Plan, a key component of the project management plan. They will understand how to document the approach to risk management, roles and responsibilities, risk categories, and the methodology to be used for risk assessment and response planning.
Identify Risks: This lecture focuses on the process of risk identification. Students will learn techniques for identifying potential risks, such as expert judgment, documentation reviews, and information gathering. They will understand the importance of creating and maintaining a Risk Register to capture all identified risks.
Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis: Students will delve into the qualitative assessment of risks. They will learn how to prioritize risks by assessing their impact and probability using techniques like the risk probability and impact matrix. The lecture will cover how to use the results to prioritize risks for further analysis.
Perform Quantitative Risk Analysis: This lecture explores the quantitative assessment of risks. Students will learn how to assign numerical values to risk factors and use tools like Monte Carlo simulations to quantitatively analyze risks. They will also understand how to assess the potential impact on project objectives.
Plan Risk Responses: Students will learn how to develop risk response strategies for the identified risks. They will understand how to create a Risk Response Plan that outlines specific actions to address each risk, such as risk avoidance, risk mitigation, risk transfer, or risk acceptance.
Implement Risk Responses: Building on risk response planning, this lecture covers the implementation of risk response strategies. Students will learn how to execute the planned risk responses and take necessary actions to manage risks as they unfold during the project.
Monitor Risks: In the final lecture, students will explore the ongoing process of monitoring and controlling risks. They will learn how to track identified risks, assess the effectiveness of risk responses, and update the Risk Register as necessary. This continuous monitoring ensures that project risks are effectively managed throughout the project's lifecycle.


Join us on this journey, and embark on a transformational experience that will elevate your project management skills to new heights. Embrace the power of risk management and seize the opportunities of the modern world with confidence and competence. Your success begins here.
target_audience: Ideal for those looking to establish a strong foundation in project risk management to kickstart their careers.
Designed to empower seasoned project managers, engineers, and various industry professionals with advanced risk management techniques for career advancement.
Valuable for individuals seeking to navigate project uncertainties, control budgets, and drive success in their ventures.
Suitable for continuous learners and those interested in applying risk management principles across a range of industries and areas of expertise.

courses.description:
Welcome to the Six Sigma White Belt Certification course! This introductory course is designed to empower you with the foundations of Six Sigma, one of the most respected and sought-after methodologies in quality management. Whether you’re a professional looking to elevate your problem-solving skills, a student eager to dive into process improvement, or simply curious about the principles of Six Sigma, this course offers you the perfect starting point.
In this course, you’ll gain a comprehensive understanding of Six Sigma, including the essential tools, methodologies, and Lean principles that will help you make an impact in any organization or industry. By the end, you’ll be equipped with the knowledge and confidence to continue your Six Sigma journey or apply the White Belt tools in real-world situations.
What You’ll Learn:
The fundamentals of Six Sigma and its impact on quality management
Key Six Sigma concepts like Critical-to-Quality (CTQ) metrics, the Cost of Poor Quality (COPQ), and process variation
The DMAIC Framework (Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control) and its applications
Basic Six Sigma tools, including Fishbone Diagrams, Pareto Charts, and Process Flowcharts
How Lean principles work with Six Sigma to eliminate waste and optimize efficiency
Real-world case studies that show Six Sigma in action across various industries
Why Enroll in This Course?
In-Demand Skills: Six Sigma is recognized globally and in demand across multiple industries, from manufacturing to healthcare to business.
Career Boost: Stand out to employers by adding White Belt certification to your resume.
Practical Knowledge: Learn essential tools and strategies you can apply to real-world problems, even at the entry level.
Step-by-Step Guidance: This course is designed to be beginner-friendly, with clear, simple explanations of each concept and tool.
Course Breakdown:

courses.description:
the pursuit of excellence and the commitment to continuous improvement are paramount to achieving sustained success. As organizations strive to deliver projects that meet or exceed stakeholder expectations, the integration of quality assurance and continuous improvement strategies becomes increasingly critical. This course offers an unparalleled opportunity for individuals to elevate their project management skills, adopting a mindset of relentless improvement and rigorous quality control.

Embarking on this educational journey, students will discover a rich tapestry of knowledge that seamlessly interweaves theoretical foundations with practical applications. The curriculum is meticulously designed to provide a holistic understanding of how quality assurance and continuous improvement can be harnessed to enhance project outcomes. By delving into the principles of quality management, students will gain insights into the frameworks and methodologies that underpin successful quality initiatives, such as Six Sigma, Lean, and Total Quality Management (TQM).

The course is structured to foster a deep comprehension of the various dimensions of quality in the context of project management. Students will explore the intricate relationships between quality planning, quality assurance, and quality control, and how these elements contribute to the overall success of a project. The emphasis on quality planning equips students with the skills to identify quality requirements and establish robust quality objectives, ensuring that projects are aligned with organizational goals and stakeholder expectations from the outset.

A pivotal aspect of the learning experience is the focus on quality assurance processes. Students will be introduced to systematic approaches for monitoring and evaluating project performance, identifying deviations from quality standards, and implementing corrective actions. Through a series of case studies and real-world examples, students will learn how to apply quality assurance techniques to mitigate risks and enhance project deliverables. The practical application of these concepts ensures that students are not only able to comprehend theoretical knowledge but also to translate it into actionable strategies within their own projects.

As the course progresses, students will delve into the principles and practices of continuous improvement. Emphasizing the importance of a culture of continuous enhancement, the curriculum explores various methodologies for driving incremental and breakthrough improvements. Students will learn how to utilize tools such as process mapping, root cause analysis, and the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycle to identify opportunities for improvement and implement sustainable changes. These skills are invaluable for fostering an environment where innovation and excellence are continually pursued.

One of the unique features of this course is its emphasis on the human aspect of quality and continuous improvement. Recognizing that successful implementation of quality initiatives requires more than just technical skills, the course addresses the essential role of leadership, communication, and team collaboration. Students will explore strategies for leading quality improvement efforts, fostering a culture of accountability, and engaging stakeholders in the quality journey. By developing these soft skills, students will be well-equipped to inspire and motivate their teams, driving collective commitment to quality and continuous improvement.

The learning experience is further enriched by the integration of cutting-edge technology and tools that are transforming the landscape of project management. Students will be introduced to advanced software and digital solutions that facilitate quality management and continuous improvement. From data analytics platforms that provide actionable insights to automated quality control systems that enhance efficiency, the course equips students with the knowledge to leverage technology in their quest for excellence.

The potential impact of this course on students' personal and professional development is profound. By mastering the principles of quality assurance and continuous improvement, students will be positioned as invaluable assets to their organizations. They will possess the skills to drive project success, enhance operational efficiency, and deliver superior value to stakeholders. The knowledge and competencies gained from this course will set students apart as leaders in the field of project management, opening doors to advanced career opportunities and professional growth.

Furthermore, the course fosters a lifelong commitment to learning and improvement. Students will be encouraged to adopt a mindset of curiosity and adaptability, continuously seeking new ways to enhance their skills and contribute to their organizations' success. The emphasis on continuous improvement extends beyond the confines of the course, inspiring students to apply the principles they have learned to all aspects of their personal and professional lives.

This course offers a comprehensive and engaging exploration of quality assurance and continuous improvement in project management. Through a blend of theoretical knowledge, practical applications, and experiential learning, students will acquire the skills and insights needed to excel in their careers. The commitment to fostering a culture of quality and continuous improvement will empower students to drive project success, enhance organizational performance, and achieve their professional aspirations. Enrolling in this course is an investment in your future, equipping you with the tools to navigate the complexities of the modern project management landscape and emerge as a leader committed to excellence.

courses.description:
In this 'How to fill your PMP application? video course, I teach you everything you need to know to pass the PMP certification exam application process and avoid unnecessary stress.
The PMI PMP application reviewers have an eye to spot things such as plagiarism, coy-paste, project descriptions that sound more like operation than real project work, etc. which results in rejected PMP applications. PMP application rejections are more common than you might think.
There's also a certain percentage of PMP applications that get picked up for an audit.
It doesn't matter if you have a lot of project management experience; we've found that senior project managers have a harder time getting their PMP applications approved than junior project managers because their applications tend to focus on leadership and outcomes, which the PMI reviewers aren't interested in.
Also, rewritten and resubmitted PMP applications usually face an automatic audit and greater scrutiny.
Avoid all this stress, you don't need it!!
Enroll in this course and understand everything you need to know about writing the PMP application and passing any audits should you get picked up.


Here's what you will learn in this course:
1. What is the Project Management Professional (PMP) exam?
2. How to gauge if you are eligible for the PMP certification exam?
3. Best practices and top-notch tips related to filling the application
4. Strategies to not getting your PMP application rejected
5. How to succeed if you are picked up for a PMP application audit?
6. Working example of a real PMP application
7. PMP application examples
8. PMP application 500 character description
9. PMP application requirements
10. Sample PMP application form PDF provided
11. PMP application template excel 2021
12. PMP application project description examples
We provide PMP application reviews and rewrites with 99.9% approval rates.
Email us at info@careersprints.com.


PMP Qualification Criteria
To be eligible for the PMP® certification credential, you must meet both educational and professional experience requirements. Some of the key requirements are given below.


Minimum Experience Requirements
1. All project management experience must have been gained within the last 8 consecutive years prior to application submission.
2. A secondary degree (high school diploma, associate's degree, or global equivalent) AND a minimum of five years/60 months of unique non-overlapping professional Project Management experience during which at least 7500 hours were spent leading and directing project tasks
OR
A four-year degree (bachelor's degree or global equivalent) AND a minimum of three years/35 months unique non-overlapping professional project management experience during which at least 4500 hours were spent leading and directing project tasks.


PMI Audit Process
The submission of an application indicates your agreement to comply with the terms of the audit process. All applications are subject to an audit, although only a percentage of applications are selected for audit.


If your application is selected for an audit, you will be notified by email prior to payment of the certification fee. The electronic audit notification provides detailed information on how to comply with the terms of the audit.


During an audit, you will be asked to submit supporting documentation such as:
- Copies of your diploma/global equivalent
- Signatures from your supervisor(s) or manager(s) from the project(s) are recorded in the experience verification section of the application
- Copies of certificates and/or letters from the training institute(s) for each course recorded on the application to meet the required contact hours of professional education PMI provides you with 90 days to submit the requested documentation.


If you are able to provide the necessary documentation to meet the terms and requirements of the audit process, the audit should take about five to seven business days to complete.


You can send your completed audit forms by regular postal mail or express courier service, to the address below.


Please send all materials at one time, in one envelope.


Sending audit documents separately can cause a delay in the audit review timeframe.


PMI Attn: Certification Audit
14 Campus Blvd.
Newtown Square, PA 19073-3299 USA

courses.description:
This is an introductionary training course about Project Management according to ISO 21500 and ISO 21502.
ISO 21502:2020: "Project, Programme and Portfolio Management - Guidance on Project Management" is the international standard for project management. It is applicable to most organizations, including public and private organizations and it is not dependent on the size or the type of the organization.
Although ISO 21500 was first released in 2012 as the Guidance on Project Management, it eventually became a standard family in 2021, hence replaced by ISO 21502 as the standard guide on project management. It is somewhat comparable to ISO 9000 vs. ISO 9001, where ISO 9000 is a family of quality management standards and ISO 9001 is the standard that millions of organizations get certified.
•ISO 21502 Certificate indicates that you / your organization has the required knowledge about project management methods and implementation of those methods for better management.
•It is globally recognized and a merit that demonstrates the project management skills of you, your executive personnel and managers.
•It can be a condition or requirement for some contracts and bids.
•Your customers will know that you plan your projects correctly, execute your projects efficiently and provide top-quality products and services thanks to better project management.
target_audience: People who want to be introduced to project management with international standards.

The practice exams include the right answer, the clarification for the correct answer, and the question reference in the PMBOK  and RISK  STANDARD.
The practice exams included different examples of each type of the commonly found questions on the PMI-RMP Exam.
This course of the "PMI-RMP" Real practice exams is the best way for the PMI-RMP candidate to improve his knowledge and to see the areas of weakness and strengths.
Risk is an uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative effect on one or more objectives. Positive risks are opportunities, while negative risks are threats. The practice of risk management includes planning the approach, identifying and analyzing risks, response planning and implementation, and ongoing monitoring of risks. Risk management is an essential aspect of all organizational activities. This standard describes the application of risk management within an enterprise risk management (ERM) context that includes the portfolio, program, and project domains. Risk management shapes the decision-making processes across the organization and within each of the domains .
Successful organizations are able to effectively and efficiently identify the risks that directly influence goals and objectives. The challenge for most organizations is making the best use of resources by focusing on the right risks. This depends on the characteristics of the organization, its environment, internal maturity, culture, and strategy. Determining the most impactful risks can be difficult. Organizations develop and improve by refining the processes for risk prioritization.
target_audience: Project Managers , Risk Manager, Planners, Cost Engineers, Quantity Surveyors, Project Control Engineers Sr. Managers and All employees working in projects

courses.description:
Risk management should not only help companies to achieve minimum legal compliance requirements but also contribute to the demonstrable achievement of objectives, linking risks with performance. According to ISO31000 standard, integrating risk management into an organization is a dynamic and iterative process, and should be customized to the organization’s needs and culture. Risk management should be a part of, and not separate from, the organizational governance, leadership, strategy, operations and performance management.
Alex Sidorenko has created a 25-step program to integrate risk management into decision making, core business processes and the overall culture of the organization. This course covers practical steps to design, implement and measure effectiveness of risk management.
This course will help you answer the following questions:
Do key stakeholders believe risk management is aligned with strategy, objectives and culture and helps the organization achieve its objectives?
Is there a risk management statement or policy?
Does management show commitment to the integration of risk management into all processes or decision types, giving risk team sufficient resources and responsibility?
Is responsibility for risk management as part of business activities and decision making regularly communicated by top management to management and staff?
Are oversight bodies confident that risks have been adequately considered when setting the organization’s objectives?
Is information about risks and their management presented in the reports that oversight bodies receive and included in any significant decisions they have to make?
Are results of independent risk management effectiveness assessments presented to the oversight bodies on a regular basis?
Is risk management effort consistent with internal and external environment (meeting both regulatory requirements and stakeholder expectations)?
Have risk management principles been integrated into existing policies and procedures instead of just having a single aggregated risk management framework document?
Has the responsibility for risk identification and analysis been documented in the committee charters, policies, procedures and job descriptions?
Does risk management team have the necessary resources to effectively integrate risk management into business activities and decision making?
Is information about risks and their management integrated in existing financial and management reporting?
Does an organization have a plan to implement risk management into all activities throughout the organization, including decision-making?
Are significant decisions and approvals made by the management only after analysing the risks associated with these decisions?
Is risk management integrated into planning, budgeting, motivation and performance management processes instead of having a standalone risk management process?
Are strategic goals, objectives and key performance indicators set based on the results of the risk analysis?
Is risk management integrated in core operational processes, risks are analysed on an ongoing basis within operating activities?
Are key supporting (back-office) processes organized in such a way, that risks and their treatments are considered?
Is risk-based decision making consistently applied across subsidiaries, key suppliers and supply chains?
Are risk management competences developed in all key departments?
Are risk management competences integrated in the training and development program for employees, is there regular risk management training for different levels of management?
Are risk management competences an important attribute when applying for jobs in the organization?
Do you consider organization has a strong culture dedicated to risk-based decision making and risk management?

According to a PMI study conducted in 2021, The Global Economy is facing a significant shortage of project management professionals, with an estimated need for 25 million new employees by 2030. To address this gap, 2.3 Million individuals must enter the field annually.

When demand dramatically exceeds supply, salaries offered will increase significantly. With an influx of "newbie" project managers entering the market, competition will intensify. Meanwhile, experienced professionals boasting 5+ years of expertise will become even more expensive to hire.

If you are reading this, you are already interested in project management. This is great! You've got two promising paths to maximize your gains:
Transition into a full-time project manager role.
Develop project management as a skill alongside your subject matter expertise. (e.g. Marketing expert who can lead a project)
Regardless of the path you choose, especially if you excel, you'll inevitably encounter a threshold where the volume and complexity of projects you handle will push your limits. No matter your skill level, everyone has their breaking point.

To surpass this point, you'll need to take two crucial steps:
Adopt a project methodology
Start using a project management tool
Many project managers put off using structured methods and prefer to rely on intuition and manual processes. They might say they know Microsoft Project on their CVs, even if they haven't used it much or at all.

courses.description:
Understanding the Basics of Commercial Management in the Construction Industry
This Basic course will introduce you to the fundamental concepts and principles of commercial management in the construction industry. You will learn about the role of commercial managers, the different areas of commercial management, and the relationship between commercial management and other disciplines.
The course will cover the following topics:
What is commercial management?
Commercial management is the process of managing the financial aspects of a construction project. This includes activities such as budgeting, forecasting, and contract management.
Commercial managers are responsible for ensuring that construction projects are completed on time, within budget, and to the required quality standards.
The role of commercial managers
Commercial managers play a vital role in the construction industry. They are responsible for:
Developing and managing project budgets
Negotiating contracts with suppliers and contractors
Managing risks and ensuring that projects are completed on time and within budget
Ensuring that projects meet the required quality standards
The relationship between commercial management and other disciplines
Commercial management is closely related to other disciplines, such as:
Project planning and scheduling
Budget and financial management
Contract management
Risk management
Quality management


=> Project planning and scheduling management
Project planning and scheduling is the process of developing a plan for how a project will be completed.
Planning and Scheduling Management Process:
1.  Define the scope of the project
2. Develop the project schedule
3. Identify and manage risks
4. Allocate resources
5. Monitor and control the project
=> Budget and Financial management
Budget and financial management is the process of tracking and managing the financial resources of a project.
Budget and Financial Management Process:
1.  Define the project
2. Estimate the costs
3. Develop a budget
Cost report or Financial report
=> Contract management
Contract management is the process of negotiating, managing, and enforcing contracts.
Contract Management Process:
1.  Negotiating contracts
2. Executing contracts
3. Administering contracts
=> Risk management
Risk management is the process of identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks.
Risk Management Process:
1.  Identify the risks
2. Assess the risks
3. Develop mitigation strategies
4. Implement the mitigation strategies
5. Monitor and review the risk management plan
=> Quality management
Quality management is the process of ensuring that a project meets the required quality standards.
Quality Management Process:
1.  Set quality standards
2. Measure performance
3. Take corrective action
4. Continuous improvement
By the end of this course, you will learn the basics of:
Develop and manage project budgets
Negotiate contracts with suppliers and contractors
Manage risks and ensure that projects are completed on time and within budget
Ensuring that projects meet the required quality standards
If you are interested in a career in commercial management in the construction industry, or if you want to improve your skills and knowledge in this field, then this course is for you. Enroll today and begin your journey to becoming a successful assistant / commercial manager.
target_audience: Anyone related to or interested in a career in construction such as Construction managers/ Engineers, Project managers/ Engineers, Contract managers/ Contract administrators, Cost Engineers, architects, Fresh graduates engineers, real estate developers and quantity surveyors

courses.description:
This course will be covering all about the risk management process starting from the planning, identifying your risks and categorizing your risks in your project and the techniques for identifying risks in risk management. This course will cover the two analysis processes in risk management qualitative and quantitative analysis.
In qualitative we will learn about how to determine your risk score or risk index by using probability and the impact of each risk so that we could grade them on the risk matrix scale to see which risks require a response. We will also cover the quantitative risk analysis process to further analyze the risks that have moved forward. We will look at sensitivity analysis to know about the tornado diagram. Schedule and cost uncertainty will be covered and we’ll talk about triangular distribution and beta distribution.
We will learn how Monte Carlo simulation uses all this information to estimate the possible outcomes of an uncertain event. You’ll learn about the distribution graph and the distribution analyzer and how to read your project outcomes from these graphs. We will then cover planning risk responses to all your risks and how to monitor and control them and what should your outcomes after doing risk management be.
target_audience: Anyone that wants to effectively manage risks

courses.title: Conduct Better Post Mortems | Projects | Incidents
courses.bio: Blameless post mortems | Celebrate and Amplify Success | Avoid Future Failures | Learn and Grow
objectives: Discover why post-mortems are vital for project success and continuous improvement
Master the step-by-step process of conducting effective post-mortem analyses
Discover techniques to foster blame-free environments in project teams
Understand how to integrate post-mortems into your project management practices
Gain insights on building a culture of continuous improvement for project success

Post Mortem Processes: Hands On : A Post Mortem Document
Creating a Culture of Improvements: Introduction to a Culture of Improvement
Building The Habit : The Importance of Regular Post Mortems

requirements: Project management experience, whether leading a project or being on a team, will be helpful
courses.description:
Post mortems are an incredibly important tool in project management, incident response and other areas of business. They not only help groups avoid negative problems, but also enhance positive outcomes by digging in and learning what works.
Additionally, post mortems are not a way to blame a team or an individual - they're a way for the group to improve and do better. Cultivating a blame-free environment when conducting post mortems is critical to their success.
This course is designed around two main sections:
Section 1 - How to conduct a post mortem
This section covers how to run a post mortem successfully, and includes things like:
Defining what will be included in your post mortem process
How to collect information - including identifying who should be involved and what information you need
Analyzing what you find - Drawing conclusions from all that data
Conducting a post mortem meeting - getting everyone together to brainstorm how to do better next time
Implementing improvements - How you'll take what you've learned and make it real
Section 2 - Cultivating a culture of improvement
This section focuses on how to help your team focus on improving, and moving away from blaming. Lectures include:
Building buy in - Convincing others that post-mortems are important can be hard, start small and build out.
Making a habit of post mortems - They shouldn't be only only on special occasions, do them for every project to help build a habit
Blameless - post mortems aren't meant to blame, instead they're meant to help us all do better


Who Should Enroll
This course is meant for anyone who might be involved in a post mortem, or expected to run one. Examples of roles that tend to do this include:
Software Engineers: Analyze system failures and identify improvements
Systems Managers: Determine the cause of system faults and avoid them
Analysts: Figure out why a project is successful and help others do the same
Customer Support : Pull apart an escalation and avoid them
Project Managers: Ensure project closure with effective post-mortems, especially following unexpected challenges.
Scrum Masters: Augment your toolkit with practices that foster team growth and efficiency.
Why Choose This Course:
Every project ,incident, escalation, failure, success (and more!) should be analyzed to see why it happened. You should choose this course because you want to learn from success (and failure), and because you want your team to focus on improving - not blame.
target_audience: Project managers looking to improve how they run post-mortems
Individuals wanting to improve their project management skills
Individuals wanting to improve how their teams learn from their projects
Teams wanting to implement a culture of improvement

courses.description:
Understanding your customer, their needs and their requirements is crucially important - probably the most important thing you need to grasp in your business. To obtain this knowledge, you need a tool that will help you to gain the crucial insights to help you shape your products and services. This is where the CTQ (critical to quality) Tree tool comes in.
This tool enables you to work logically though a process, whether on your own, as a business or with your customer to establish their needs, what drives the successful delivery of these needs and the SLAs (service level agreements) that sit around them. The tool is multifaceted, giving you greater insight into what your customer wants but also enabling you to make better, more informed decisions and create lasting and achievable SLAs.
In this course, we do the following:
- Go through the fundamentals of this tool (what CTQ is, what the tool is, the benefits and customer analysis).
- We walk through the process you need to follow in order to deliver the tool.
- We break the tool down into its constituent parts and explain each, in detail.
- There are also several demonstrations, based on real life examples of CTQ Trees being deployed in a range of scenarios.
- And we will give hints and tips along the way to ensure you are covered when looking to deploy this tool.
Being able to understand your customer's needs today, tomorrow and longer term is a skill highly in demand and insight that is non-negotiable for any successful business. With the CTQ Tree, you get just that!
target_audience: Anyone currently working for a company who wants to improve their customer experience
Anyone who owns a business / manages a department and wants to improve their customer experience
Anyone who wants to upskill in this field as understanding what is critical to your customers is a skill HIGHLY in demand
Anyone who wants to leave the course with full confidence of the critical to quality tree

courses.description:
Project Planning and Scheduling is one of the most important activities for a Project Manager when starting and managing any type of project. Many mistakes are made during the first few weeks shaping the project scope, leading up to a plan and a schedule. During my career as Project Manager and Manager of Project Management Offices I have come across many emerging and junior Project Managers who were lacking the initial understanding of what was important for the lead up to building a schedule.
This course is written for beginners and Project Management juniors, so that you will learn what Project Planning and Scheduling is about.
After completion of this course
you will have an understanding of various Project Management methodologies;
you will be able to discuss the difference between planning and scheduling;
you will know what it takes how to create a workable schedule,
you will know what you need to do to establish good and meaningful Project Performance Reporting; and
you will learn about tools for scheduling and Project Portfolio Management on a high level.
My teams over the years have compiled a number of tips and tricks to make life of a Project Manager more predictable. I have added a number of them in this course, so you will be well prepared to start your first project and avoid doing rookie mistakes.The course takes just under 2 hours and is filled with great material for you to learn about the basics of Project Management Methodologies; how to derive a plan and schedule from the project scope and objectives, create a schedule that you can work with, what you should look out for when monitoring and controlling project performance and finally, which scheduling tool or Project Portfolio Management tool would be suitable.If you want to successfully manage your first few projects and get a head start following what seasoned Project Managers already do, this course is for you! You will no doubt grasp the concepts of Project Planning and Scheduling and apply them straight away in your career as a Project Manager.
target_audience: This course is developed for beginners, newbies to Project Management, who would like to understand on a high level what project scheduling and planning encompasses during the project lifecycle
This course provides some tips on how to create a schedule that a Project Manager can work with.

Confluence is the home for all the information your development team needs to keep projects moving forward. It’s where you assemble the plans, requirements, decisions, and documentation behind your software. It’s also the place that connects your development team to product managers, designers, marketers, and other colleagues who participate in the software development process. Confluence is your common ground. It’s the one place where anyone can access and contribute to what you’re working on.
Equipped with Confluence, your team can make quick decisions, gain alignment, and accomplish more together. Scrum teams can leverage Confluence for building requirements. With the ready-to-go requirements template, you can gather your requirements from the team using the collaborative editor and negotiate details with stakeholders using inline comments. When you've all agreed on the final requirements, it is easy to convert them into Jira issues with just a few clicks directly from Confluence.
Confluence is also good for keeping up with decisions, running retrospectives at the end of your sprint cycle, and keeping meeting notes.

The Plan and Define Project Scope (PMI - PMP) is course 6 of 28 of the Project Management Professional Certification Program (PMI-PMP). The course is aligned with the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK6) developed by the Project Management Institute (PMI).
Your project is all approved, and you're ready to get started. What's the first step? You need to figure out exactly what the end result is going to look like based on the customer's needs.
In this course, you'll learn how to plan scope management for your project, use the collect requirements process to gather and refine stakeholders' requirements. And then how to turn those into your scope statement with the defined scope process.
1. Defining Project Scope

That’s it! Now go ahead and push that “Take this course” button, and see you on the inside!
